taxon_identification.other_info_on_name: [Latin sagina , ancient name for Spergula once included in Sagina , a feasting, fatten, alluding to early use as forage]

references.reference: Crow, G. E. 1978. A taxonomic revision of Sagina (Caryophyllaceae) in North America. Rhodora 80: 1–91.
Crow, G. E. 1979. The systematic significance of seed morphology in Sagina (Caryophyllaceae) utilizing SEM. Brittonia 31: 52–63.

key_statement.description: Petals nearly 2 times sepals, 3–4.5 mm; distal cauline leaves and lateral branches usually with axillary fascicles of minute, succulent leaves, giving knotted appearance

Petals shorter than, equaling, or barely longer than sepals, 0.8–3 mm, or absent; cauline leaves and procumbent stems sometimes with axillary fascicles resembling cauline leaves, not minute, succulent.
Flowers 5-merous; leaf blades fleshy; seeds reniform or nearly globose, plump, abaxial groove absent.
Calyx bases and distal portion of pedicels glabrous
Calyx bases and distal portion of pedicels glandular-pubescent.
Seeds reddish brown, smooth or slightly pebbled
Seeds dark brown, usually distinctly tuberculate or strongly pebbled
Flowers 4–5-merous; leaf blades not fleshy, or if slightly fleshy, then flowers predominantly 4-merous; seeds obliquely triangular, with abaxial groove.
Plants annual; stems filiform; distal cauline leaf blades subulate, becoming shorter distally.
Flowers 5-merous (rarely 4-merous, and then apetalous); leaf blade bases never ciliate; capsules longer than sepals
Flowers 4-merous, rarely 4- and 5-merous; leaf blade bases distinctly ciliate, especially of distal cauline leaves; capsules equaling or barely longer than sepals
Plants perennial; stems not filiform; distal cauline leaf blades linear, linear-subulate, or, if subulate, then plants cespitose.
Plants cespitose, forming low cushions; cauline leaf blades subulate; hyaline sepal margins purple.
Flowers 4-merous, sometimes accompanied by 5-merous flowers; petals shorter than or equaling sepals, 1.5–2 mm; primary basal rosette of fleshy, subulate leaves present, secondary rosettes absent

Flowers 5-merous, sometimes accompanied by 4-merous flowers; petals longer than or rarely equaling sepals, 2.5–3 mm; primary basal rosette of leaves absent, secondary rosettes of linear leaves often present
Plants with stems ascending, spreading, procumbent, or mat-forming (sometimes cespitose in alpine sites); leaf blades linear; hyaline sepal margins white.
Flowers 4-merous, sometimes accompanied by 5-merous flowers; petals 0.8–1 mm, sometimes absent; sepals divergent at time of capsule dehiscence
Flowers 5-merous; petals (1–)1.5–2 mm; sepals appressed to loosely appressed at time of capsule dehiscence.
Plants glabrous; cauline leaf blade apices apiculate; connate leaf bases not forming conspicuous cup

Plants with leaves, stems, pedicels, and calyx bases glandular-pubescent; cauline leaf blade apices aristate, aristae equaling or exceeding leaf width; connate leaf bases forming conspicuous, scarious cup
